lessons.title: First Greetings
lessons.goal: Politely greet an adult stranger and respond to "How are you?"
lessons.grammarFocus: Singular vs plural of respect (-i suffix)
cultureNotes: Importance of first greetings and response etiquette in Shona culture
Accompanying clapping when greeting elders

activities.description: Mimic-the-audio chant: Learners repeat recorded greetings after native speaker.
Dialogue scramble – arrange shuffled greeting phrases in correct order.
Pair practice: introduce yourself to a virtual character using proper greeting formality.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction. Automatic speech evaluation checks for correct greeting form and pronunciation.

exercises.question: Which greeting is appropriate for addressing an elder?

lessons.title: Introducing Yourself
lessons.goal: State your name and where you are from.
lessons.grammarFocus: Subject prefix ndi- (I), phrases 'Zita rangu ndi…' and 'Ndinonzi…', preposition 'ku' for origin.
cultureNotes: When introducing yourself to elders, add a respectful plural form when addressing them.
Handshakes are light; clapping once before speaking shows politeness.

activities.description: Audio echo: repeat full introduction sentences after native speaker.
Drag-and-drop jigsaw: build the sentence 'Zita rangu ndi ___' from word blocks.
Meet-and-greet: record a short intro including name & hometown; the AI avatar replies.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction; speech evaluation checks correct structure and pronunciation.

exercises.question: How do you say 'My name is…' in Shona?
Which word in Shona means 'I am called'?

lessons.title: Farewells & Small Talk
lessons.goal: End a conversation politely and perform basic leave-takings.
lessons.grammarFocus: Plural forms for respect and future tense marker 'ticha-' in 'tichasangana'.
cultureNotes: 'Sarayi zvakanaka' is used when the other person is staying; 'Fambai zvakanaka' when they are leaving.
It is common to clap lightly once or twice while saying farewell to an elder.

activities.description: Call-and-response farewell chorus.
Match Shona farewells to their English meanings.
Simulated good-bye conversation choosing correct phrases for given context.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice quiz on selecting correct farewell based on scenario.

exercises.question: Which phrase means 'We will meet again'?

lessons.title: Checkpoint Challenge: Café Line-up
lessons.goal: Apply greetings, introductions and farewells in a timed café scenario.
lessons.grammarFocus: Consolidation of plural respectful forms and introduction phrases.
cultureNotes: Politeness is key when ordering; greet before requesting service.
Queue etiquette: allow elders to go first if possible.

activities.description: Interactive café queue: choose correct greeting, introduce yourself to barista, end with proper farewell.
60-second rapid-fire greetings vs farewells identification.

lessons.assessment: Scenario score: must reach 80% correct selections within time limit to pass.

exercises.question: Match each Shona phrase to its English meaning.
Which greeting should you use for a group of elders?

lessons.title: Family Members Vocabulary
lessons.goal: Identify and pronounce core Shona terms for immediate and extended family members.
lessons.grammarFocus: Noun Classes 1/1a (singular humans) with Class 2/2a plurals; respect plurals for elders.
cultureNotes: Titles like Sekuru and Ambuya extend beyond blood relation, showing community respect.
Using plural prefixes (va-) for elders conveys politeness even when singular.

activities.description: Flashcard reveal: select correct English meaning after hearing each Shona kinship term.
Drag nouns into 'Singular' or 'Plural' baskets to visualise noun-class pairs.
Label a family picture aloud; speech recognition checks pronunciation.

lessons.assessment: Picture-matching quiz: choose the correct Shona word for highlighted relative (80% to pass).

exercises.question: Match the singular to its plural.

lessons.title: Possessive Pronouns (-angu / -ako)
lessons.goal: Use possessive pronouns to describe your family members politely.
lessons.grammarFocus: Possessive suffixes (-angu, -ako, -edu) agree with noun class; keep va- prefix for respect.
cultureNotes: Over-specifying possession with elders can sound boastful; context often implies 'my'.
Clapping once before speaking to an elder shows humility.

activities.description: Hear model sentences with possessives, repeat with voice feedback.
Drag correct possessive ending to noun stems (e.g., baba ___).
Ask AI partner about their family and fill a table using -ako/-angu.

lessons.assessment: Fill-in-the-blank quiz: supply correct possessive suffix (85% to pass).

exercises.question: How do you say 'my brother' in Shona?

lessons.title: Talking About Ages
lessons.goal: State ages of family members using numbers 1-20 and structure 'ane ___ makore'.
lessons.grammarFocus: Numbers 1-20; verb 'ane' (has) for age; avoid verb 'to be'.
cultureNotes: Exact age of elders sometimes avoided; approximate or general terms are polite.
Children proudly state age; opportunity for counting practice.

activities.description: Quick-fire counting with audio 1-20.
Virtual ID cards show digits; say age in Shona sentences.
Guess relative's age from photo then reveal and pronounce correctly.

lessons.assessment: Oral quiz via speech recognition on five random ages (80% to pass).

exercises.question: Complete: Baba vangu ___ makore makumi maviri.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Digital Family Tree
lessons.goal: Create and narrate a simple digital family tree using correct kinship terms and possessives.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review noun classes 1/2, possessive suffixes, ages with 'ane'.
cultureNotes: Start introductions with elders to show respect; include totem (mutupo) if known.

activities.description: Drag avatars onto a tree, label with Shona terms and ages.
Record 45-second narration; AI flags any incorrect grammar.

lessons.assessment: Score = 80% correct labels + acceptable pronunciation to unlock Unit 3.

exercises.question: Which noun class pair is for people?

lessons.title: This Morning – Recent Past
lessons.goal: Narrate morning activities that happened today using the recent-past marker -a-.
lessons.grammarFocus: Recent past tense (-a-) vs habitual (-no-): Ndakamuka vs Ndinomuka.
cultureNotes: Shona distinguishes between actions that happened today (recent past) and yesterday (remote past).

activities.description: Picture sequence – drag verbs to match a cartoon of morning routine.
Swap subject prefixes to practise person + -a- forms.
Learner records three sentences about their morning in recent past.

lessons.assessment: Auto-graded spoken diary must use at least two correct -a- verbs.

exercises.question: Select the recent-past form for 'I washed' (kugeza).
Translate to Shona: I got dressed.

lessons.title: Yesterday – Remote Past
lessons.goal: Contrast yesterday's events using the remote-past marker -ka-.
lessons.grammarFocus: Remote past (-ka-) for actions before today; time adverbs nezuro (yesterday).
cultureNotes: Learners appreciate the nuanced time frame encoded in Shona past tenses.

activities.description: Place sentences on timeline.

lessons.title: Connecting Events – Sequence Words
lessons.goal: Use connectors wobva (then) and pakati (while) to chain events.
lessons.grammarFocus: Subordinate clauses and sequencing connectors.
cultureNotes: Storytelling in Shona relies heavily on connectors to maintain flow.

activities.description: Order mixed sentences into a coherent paragraph.
Roll icons, compose a 4-sentence story using at least two connectors.

lessons.assessment: Short written story graded for connector accuracy.

exercises.question: Translate: After that I went to work.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Audio Diary
lessons.goal: Record a 60-second diary contrasting today vs yesterday.
lessons.grammarFocus: Assessment of recent vs remote past and connectors.

activities.description: Learner speaks; AI transcribes and highlights tense errors.
Replay annotated transcript and correct mistakes.

lessons.assessment: Must hit 80% tense accuracy to pass.

exercises.question: Which tense describes something that happened this morning?
Which word best links two actions in sequence?

lessons.title: Market Greetings & Item Names
lessons.goal: Greet vendors politely and name common produce and goods.
lessons.grammarFocus: Vendor greetings with plural of respect; question 'Munayo here…?' (Do you have…?).
cultureNotes: Always greet before asking price; vendors appreciate respect.
Use plural forms (mangwanani, makadini) even when speaking to one vendor.

activities.description: Audio flashcards: match produce pictures to Shona names.
Fill missing greeting phrases in sample vendor conversation.
Say hello and ask a virtual vendor if they have selected items.

lessons.assessment: Short recorded dialogue graded for correct greeting and item vocabulary (80%).

exercises.question: Translate to Shona: Do you have tomatoes?

lessons.title: Prices & Numbers 11–99
lessons.goal: Ask for prices and understand numbers up to 99.
lessons.grammarFocus: Number formation 11–99; structure 'Mari inosvika…' (The price reaches…).
cultureNotes: Prices are quoted in US dollars and RTGS; confirm currency.
Bargaining involves counter-offers with polite language, not aggressive haggling.

activities.description: Listen to spoken prices, mark numbers on bingo card.
Assign correct number phrases to price labels on items.
Pair exercise: one asks 'Imarii _____?' other states price.

lessons.assessment: Price-list quiz: choose correct Shona number for shown digit (85%).

exercises.question: How do you say 45 in Shona?

lessons.title: Bargaining & Polite Requests
lessons.goal: Negotiate price using polite structures and request quantities.
lessons.grammarFocus: Imperative with '-wo' for politeness; verb 'dzikisa' (reduce) in request form 'Mungadzikisewo here mutengo?'.
cultureNotes: Polite tone and small talk often secure better price reductions.
Handing money with right hand while supporting forearm shows respect.

activities.description: Convert direct commands into polite bargaining phrases.
Interactive vendor chat where learner tries to lower price.
Request 1–5 kilos of items using correct number words.

lessons.assessment: Complete simulation achieving target discount using ≥3 polite phrases.

exercises.question: Translate: Please lower the price a little.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Market Day
lessons.goal: Buy three items within budget in timed market simulation using greetings, numbers, and bargaining language.
lessons.grammarFocus: Comprehensive review of Unit 2 structures.

activities.description: Virtual market with voice/chat; learner must greet, ask price, bargain, pay.
AI summary of strengths & corrections.

lessons.assessment: Score ≥85 currency units remaining after purchases & correct language to pass.

lessons.title: Weather Vocabulary & Describing Today
lessons.goal: Describe current weather conditions using present habitual tense.
lessons.grammarFocus: Present habitual with subject prefixes (iri, vari) plus adjective stems (kupisa – hot). Structure: 'Zuva riri kupisa'.
cultureNotes: Traditional farmers observe sky colour and wind to predict rain.

activities.description: Match weather icons to Shona words.
Drag adjective to complete sentences like 'Makore ari ___'.
Record two sentences about today's weather; AI checks correctness.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice quiz on vocab & correct adjective agreement (80%).

exercises.question: Translate to Shona: It is windy.

lessons.title: Forecasting – Future Tense
lessons.goal: Talk about tomorrow's weather using future marker -cha-.
lessons.grammarFocus: Future tense subject prefix + -cha- (ichanaya – it will rain). Time adverb 'mangwana'.
cultureNotes: Zimbabwe's rainy season (Mwaka Wemvura) affects travel plans – learners connect language to culture.

activities.description: Listen to forecast, tick icons that match future conditions.
Assemble future sentences from jumbled words.
State two things you'll do tomorrow based on forecast.

lessons.assessment: Fill-in blanks with correct -cha- forms (85%).

exercises.question: Which form means 'it will be hot'?

lessons.title: Making Plans – Conditionals
lessons.goal: Use 'kana' (if) to make plans dependent on weather.
lessons.grammarFocus: Conditional clause with kana + future / habitual: 'Kana kuchinaya, ndichagara kumba'.
cultureNotes: Families plan outings around afternoon thunderstorms; conditionals common in daily talk.

activities.description: Connect halves of 'if' sentences correctly.
Spin weather wheel, state plan using kana.
Chat with AI friend arranging picnic/weather contingency.

lessons.assessment: Write two correct conditional sentences (reviewed by AI).

exercises.question: Translate: If it is hot, we will swim.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Weekly Forecast Project
lessons.goal: Create a 3-day weather forecast and corresponding activity plan.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review future tense & conditionals.

activities.description: Drag icons onto calendar, record spoken forecast.
Assign suitable activities for each forecast using kana structures.

lessons.assessment: Rubric: 3 correct future sentences + 3 correct conditional sentences (80%).

lessons.title: Hobby Vocabulary & Preferences
lessons.goal: State hobbies you like and dislike using affirmative and negative forms of 'kuda'.
lessons.grammarFocus: Verb 'kuda' (to want/like) vs negative form with prefix 'ha-' and final vowel '-i': 'Handidi kuverenga'.
cultureNotes: Football (bhora) and music (mimhanzi) are popular free-time activities across Zimbabwe.
Saying you dislike something is softer if followed by 'zvangu' (for me).

activities.description: Hear hobby verb phrases, choose matching image.
Swipe right/left on hobby cards; app forms sentence: 'Ndinoda ___' or 'Handidi ___'.
AI asks 'Unoda kutamba bhora here?' learner answers using positive or negative.

lessons.assessment: Quiz: choose correct negative/positive form for 6 hobbies (80%).

exercises.question: Translate to Shona: I like reading.

lessons.title: Frequency & Routine
lessons.goal: Describe how often you do hobbies using frequency adverbs.
lessons.grammarFocus: Placement of adverbs of frequency before verb clause: 'Kazhinji ndinotamba bhora.'
cultureNotes: Weekend names (Mugovera/Saturday, Svondo/Sunday) used for planning community sports.
Shona often omits subject pronoun when frequency adverb is present.

activities.description: Arrange scrambled words to form correct frequency sentence.
Drag hobby icons onto week planner and describe routine aloud.
Answer AI questions about how often you do each hobby.

lessons.assessment: Write/record three sentences each with different frequency adverb (80%).

lessons.title: Inviting Friends – Polite Invitations
lessons.goal: Invite someone to join your hobby politely using 'Ungada here…' and inclusive imperative 'ngati…'.
lessons.grammarFocus: Polite invitation question with 'Ungada here…?' and inclusive imperative 'Ngatimbo…'.
cultureNotes: Friends often soften invitations with food offer: 'Ngatimboenda kunwa maheu'.

activities.description: Insert correct invitation phrase into dialogue.
Invite AI friend to two hobbies; accept or decline politely.
Change statements into invitations using ngati-.

lessons.assessment: Recorded role-play scored for correct invitation forms.

exercises.question: Choose inclusive imperative meaning 'Let's go play'.
Translate: Would you like to listen to music?

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Hobby Schedule
lessons.goal: Create a weekly hobby schedule and invite a friend for one activity.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review likes/dislikes, frequency adverbs, invitations.

activities.description: Drag hobby icons onto week grid, record description.
Send AI friend an invitation using correct structures.

lessons.assessment: Rubric: 5 correct sentences + successful invitation (80%).

lessons.title: Headline Vocabulary
lessons.goal: Recognise key news topic words and identify headline gist.
lessons.grammarFocus: Nominal compounds in headlines; omission of subject prefixes.
cultureNotes: Shona newspapers often use high-frequency compounds and omit verbs for brevity.
Understanding headline structure aids quick comprehension.

activities.description: Link headline words to definition cards.
Insert missing headline word in short news lines.
Find given topic in scrambled headlines within 30 s.

lessons.assessment: 10 headline-word multiple-choice quiz (80%).

lessons.title: Listening – Short Radio Bulletin
lessons.goal: Extract main ideas from 60-second Shona radio news clip.
lessons.grammarFocus: Reported speech marker 'maererano na…' and numbers >4.
cultureNotes: VOA Shona and ZBC give concise hourly bulletins useful for learners.

activities.description: Listen once, choose broad topic (multiple-choice).
Listen again, fill numeric details (e.g., number injured).
Mark 5 statements after final listen.

lessons.assessment: Must answer 4/5 true-false correctly.

lessons.title: Summarising News
lessons.goal: Verbally summarise a short article using sequencing connectors.
lessons.grammarFocus: Past narrative tenses mix and connector sequencing.

activities.description: Order connector flashcards.
Fill template then record spoken summary.

lessons.assessment: AI rubric on 3 connectors + main facts (80%).

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Record Your News Recap
lessons.goal: Record a 90-second recap of chosen Shona news story.
lessons.grammarFocus: Assess headline vocab & sequencing.

activities.description: Pick latest VOA Shona clip.
Summarise with at least 3 connectors.

lessons.assessment: Human/AI combined score 80% to pass.

lessons.title: Respectful Address & Honorifics
lessons.goal: Use kinship terms as honorifics in social dialogue.
lessons.grammarFocus: Vocative forms and prefix Va- for politeness.
cultureNotes: Honorifics maintain social harmony; misuse can offend.

activities.description: Choose correct title when greeting different ages.
Insert titles into informal dialogue to make polite.

lessons.assessment: 8-item title selection quiz (90%).

lessons.title: Unhu/Ubuntu Expressions
lessons.goal: Understand and use proverbs that reflect the value of community.
lessons.grammarFocus: Proverb structure; negative prefix 'ha-' in moral statements.
cultureNotes: Collectivism is core; proverbs teach cooperation.

activities.description: Match proverb halves.
Choose best English paraphrase.

lessons.assessment: Explain one proverb in English (AI rubric).

lessons.title: Ceremony Vocabulary
lessons.goal: Discuss weddings & lobola using appropriate terms.
lessons.grammarFocus: Class 1 loanwords; plural forms.
cultureNotes: Lobola negotiation steps and respectful language.

activities.description: Arrange images of ceremony steps with correct terms.

lessons.assessment: 5-item vocabulary quiz.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Cultural Etiquette Quiz
lessons.goal: Score 85% on etiquette scenarios.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review honorifics & proverbs.
lessons.assessment: Scenario-based multiple choice.

lessons.title: Folktale Vocabulary
lessons.goal: Learn key story words (king, forest, trickster).
lessons.grammarFocus: Class 9/10 animal nouns and agreement.
cultureNotes: Animals in ngano carry moral qualities – tsuro (hare) clever, gudo (baboon) greedy.

activities.description: Match word to picture.

lessons.assessment: 10 vocab matching.

lessons.title: Listening – Short Ngano
lessons.goal: Comprehend 2-minute folktale and answer comprehension questions.
lessons.grammarFocus: Narrative remote past -ka- forms.
lessons.assessment: 5 comprehension Qs.

lessons.title: Retelling the Story
lessons.goal: Retell folktale using connectors and dialogue markers.
lessons.grammarFocus: Dialogue verb 'akati' (said).
lessons.assessment: AI evaluates 100-word retell.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Record Your Ngano
lessons.goal: Create and record short original folktale.
lessons.grammarFocus: Narrative past.
lessons.assessment: Peer/AI rubric.

lessons.title: Manyika vs Standard – Vocabulary Differences
lessons.goal: Recognise 10 common Manyika words differing from Standard Shona.
lessons.grammarFocus: Sound shifts zh/nz, vowel drop.
cultureNotes: Dialects show regional identity – respect speaker preference.

activities.description: Match dialect word columns.

lessons.assessment: Quick match quiz.

lessons.title: Listening – Korekore Speaker
lessons.goal: Identify dialect markers in audio clip.
lessons.grammarFocus: Retroflex sounds.
lessons.assessment: Dialect identification quiz.

lessons.title: Code-Switch Practice
lessons.goal: Rephrase sentence from standard to Manyika dialect.
lessons.grammarFocus: Sound substitution rules.
lessons.assessment: AI auto-check substitutions.

lessons.title: Checkpoint – Dialect Quiz
lessons.goal: Score 80% on dialect recognition & vocab differences.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review.
lessons.assessment: Final quiz.
